passage.text: Osmotic stress-dependent serine phosphorylation of the histidine kinase homologue DokA

The first in vivo demonstration of a stimulus-dependent serine phosphorylation of an eukaryotic histidine kinase homologue was observed. This implies that DokA, while exhibiting typical structural traits of such bacterial systems, may be involved in the erythromycin-mediated signal transduction pathway.

Proteins are often modular and composed of multiple structural units, with immunoglobulin domains, epidermal growth factor-like repeats (Ig), fibronectin-type III, Fn3, and ecg-1 (Fn3) being among the most frequently found modules in extracellular regions. The L domain(s) of the IR and EGF families have been identified as leucine-rich repeat proteins, while the IGF-1R is listed as a member of this superfamily.

These studies suggest that PP5 plays a role in controlling nucleocytoplasmic shuttling and that the suppression of pythonic regulatory protein 5 (PP5) leads to nuclear accumulation of highly reactive GRs without the presence of any hormone. This implies that there is likely more nuclear activity associated with the increase in generative gene expression (GR)-induced transcriptional activity after ISIS 15534 induced translation from Greek, suggesting that this may be due to either nuclear upregulation or export of genetically modified genes.
